description: Erection of rear L shaped dormer extension, installation of 2 x rooflights to front roof slope and single storey rear extension
decision_conditions: The proposed erection of a rear L shaped dormer extension, installation of 2 x rooflights to the front roof slope and a single storey rear extension falls within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A, B and C of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached two storey dwelling and is covered by a TPO group order.Proposal Erection of two-storey side, and single-storey rear extensions with associated changes to fenestration. Conversion of existing garage into habitable space and new porch.Consultations14 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  RBK's Trees and Landscape Officer - no objectionsThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the protected trees; and,- The impact of the development on car parking facilities; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed two storey side extension replacing the existing garage would be of the similar width of approximately 2.7m. The existing separation distance between the proposal and the adjoining property would remain.  It is noted that the proposed first floor extension would be set back from the front elevation and the proposed roof would be set approximately 0.3m from the existing roof line. As such the proposed design, scale and the roof form is considered to be subordinate and proportionate addition to the host dwelling.The proposed conversion of the garage into habitable room with associated alterations and front porch extension are considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. The proposal would be visible within the street view, however considering its modest scale and the proposed design and materials as well as similar developments present within the immediate surrounding area, it is considered that there would be no significant impact on the existing  street scene. With regards to the proposed single storey rear extension, due to its modest scale and the proposed design is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting, separation distance and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.Officer response:The Trees and Landscapes Officer has reviewed the proposal and raised no objections. As the proposal would not affect the protected trees, it is considered that there would be no significant impact on the protected trees as a result of the proposed development. Loss of Car ParkingOfficer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network. Officers note no parking restrictions on Manor Drive. In relation to cycle parking, officers note that access to the garden will remain so it is possible for secure cycle parking to be provided in the garden despite the loss of possible storage within the existing garage.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy which is considered acceptable. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
